active_learning.discussion_prompt: In groups, debate whether user training or technical email filters are more effective against malicious attachment delivery. Use evidence from NIST SP 800-83 (Guide to Malware Incident Prevention and Handling) and MITRE ATT&CK (T1566.001: Spearphishing Attachment) to support arguments, considering real-world evasion techniques like macro-enabled documents and obfuscated payloads. Address misconceptions about 'perfect' defenses.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Penetration Testing and Ethical Hacking. Topic: Malicious Attachment Delivery (Category: Cybersecurity, Domain: Penetration Testing And Ethical Hacking, Subdomain: Social Engineering Testing, Entry Domain: 007_Digital Attack Vectors and Techniques, Entry Subdomain: Email-Based Attacks, Level 6). Use the provided Learning Objectives (spanning Bloom's: Remember to Create), Active Learning components (discussion, peer teaching, problem-solving), 4-Layer Scaffolding (Foundation to Integration), and Flashcard Schema to generate 40-50 high-quality flashcards. Incorporate: - Voter consensus: Correct MITRE T1566.001, NIST SP 800-83, ACSC; prior knowledge links; real-world mocks. - Research: Malware defs (NIST), Spearphishing (MITRE), social engineering. - Pedagogy: University-style (active learning, scaffolding), formative MCQs/reflections. Output ONLY in JSON array of flashcards, each matching Schema: {front, back: {answer, explanation, bloom_level, scaffolding_layer, related_activity}}. Ensure distractors follow protocol. Cover all layers/objectives evenly. Sources: MITRE ATT&CK, NIST SP 800-83, ACSC Essential Eight, CISA.
